transcripts.text: Why is Hillary Clinton attacking Tulsi Gabbard?  We're going to connect all the dots right here and now.  Tulsi Gabbard went on The View today and she defended herself against these baseless smears.  Take a look.
Let's take a look at that.

I'm not making any predictions, but I think they've got their eye on somebody who's currently in the Democratic primary and are grooming her to be the third party candidate.  She's a favorite of the Russians.  They have a bunch of you know, sites and bots and other ways of supporting her so far.  And that's assuming Jill Stein will give it up, which she might not because she's also a Russian asset.

Really?  I mean, this is outrageous.  This is outrageous and offensive on so many levels.  I've served as a member of Congress now for almost seven years, receiving high-level national security and intelligence briefings, serving on the Foreign Affairs Committee, the Armed Services Committee, the Homeland Security Committee, working to ensure the safety and security of the people of this country.  This is why I'm running for president, to continue that commitment of service.

Are you surprised, though, that when people see bots and things and all the things that we've sort of been seeing heading your way, that people have these questions?  Because she's not the only one.  Hillary, I don't think, is the only one.  What she's saying is she feels they are grooming you.  You're saying nobody's grooming me.  I'm doing what I'm doing because I'm a soldier and a patriot.
It's offensive to me as a soldier, as an American, as a member of Congress, as a veteran, and frankly, as a woman.  to be so demeaned in such a way.
But you called her the personification of Iraq.

So demeaned in such a way.  She's a woman, too.  Well, I'm pointing to the fact that she has continued this legacy of being the world's police around the world that has waged wars costing the lives of thousands of my brothers and sisters in uniform.  I'm speaking out against that.  and to change... What's your evidence to that?  To change... Well, can I... Are you serious?  Let's hear it.  Are you serious?
I served in the war in Iraq.  Not you, her.
You're saying that she's... Exactly.  She's a war monger.
I served in the war in Iraq.
How do you come up with that?  that she championed.  She championed a regime change war in Libya.  Did you not believe in that war?  I believe the lies that were told to us.

It is indisputable to say anything other than the fact that let me just close this out, that Hillary Clinton throughout her career has led with the foreign policy of interventionism and being the world's police going and toppling dictators in other countries that has caused such destruction and loss of life.  I'm against that.  I'm running for president to change that rather than actually debate me on the issues.  she and others are resorting to these smear tactic campaigns seeking to undermine me, smear my character, and sending a message to anyone who dissents, toe the line or you too will be smeared.

So where is this coming from?  Why is Hillary Clinton deciding to go after Tulsi Gabbard?  What is the big agenda here?  So I think we've seen this throughout the last several years.  now, Hillary Clinton going after anyone who she thinks made her lose the election.  That would be Donald Trump.  Of course, she said that he's a Russian asset, and she fueled largely the whole Russian collusion conspiracy theory.  She's called Jill Stein a Russian asset, as you saw.  And here's Jill Stein, a member of the Green Party.  Here's Donald Trump, a member of the Republican Party.  And Tulsi Gabbard, a Democrat.  And yet they're all Russian assets.  So according to Hillary Clinton, it sounds like our entire government has been infiltrated and taken over, which is absurd.  Basically, what we're seeing is that Hillary Clinton is a bitter loser, and she's really upset that she thinks Russia and Vladimir Putin cost her the election.  And now she's been seeking revenge, desperately seeking revenge, and anyone who's getting in her way is somebody that she is going to try to railroad over and call now Tulsi Gabbard a Russian asset.  And of course, with Tulsi, this also stems back to when Tulsi resigned from the DNC, saying that it was essentially rigged, and she went on and backed Bernie Sanders.  She was saying that she didn't like how the DNC was handling the election.  I guess I should say, I don't think she actually said that it was rigged.  But let's go back and figure out where all of this stems from, because there's actually quite a few connections here.  And there's the claim that Tulsi made that this foreign policy is this Bush-Clinton- foreign policy that's lumped together.  And a lot of people have criticized that saying, oh, how is that?  There's Republicans and there's Democrats and they're very, very different.  And actually they are not.  And I'll go into exactly that connection there.  So Hillary Clinton hates Vladimir Putin.  This is where it starts.  I don't really know why she started hating on him at first, but back in 2008 when she was campaigning, I can only kind of deduce that maybe she started criticizing him was because she was trying to differentiate herself from a Republican, from George Bush.  And she was criticizing the comment that Bush made when he said that he looked into Putin's soul.  And in 2008 when she was on the campaign trail, she says that Putin didn't have a soul.  So there was no soul for Bush to see because Putin was an ex-KGB agent.  So this is kind of where the bad blood seems to begin.  Then when she becomes secretary of state, she continues this hard line against Russia.  Now, Obama tried to do this reset policy with Russia where he was trying to build relations and find common ground.  And Hillary Clinton reportedly was the biggest naysayer of that policy.  policy, that she pretty much just would continue to rip on Russia.  She was criticizing them, their backing of Iran, their backing of Syria, their criticisms of NATO, their expansion plans.  She said that Putin was trying to recreate the USSR.  She said a lot of inflammatory things that were really antagonizing to the Russians.  They really didn't like it very much.  And they felt like she was the biggest deterrent when it came to this whole reset policy that they were that they were undergoing with the Obama administration.  I think the biggest mistake Obama made, one of them was hiring Hillary Clinton as Secretary of State.  Now, it really comes to a head in 2011 when Putin becomes the Prime Minister of Russia, and Hillary Clinton essentially called the election a sham.  And this really upset Vladimir Putin because he sees Hillary Clinton as a warmonger, who's into a regime change, who, you know, he thinks that she was behind Iraq and Gaddafi, and he really thinks that she's a bad actor.  So the thing is, is that when it comes to regime change, one of the earliest signs that we're about to go into one, that we're about to affect one, is criticizing the elections and saying that it's a sham, saying that this is somebody that the people of that country do not want.  And we're seeing this now in Venezuela.  They're saying, oh, Maduro, it was a sham election.  They said the same thing about Hugo Chavez.  And they say this about a lot of world leaders.  They're like, oh, the election was a sham and the people don't really want him.  So when Hillary Clinton came out and publicly said that the elections in 2011 were a sham, Putin took this as a threat.  He took this as a threat to his national security.  He took this as a threat to his place in Russia.  And that is really where a lot of the bad blood kind of stemmed from.  And a lot of people that were around Putin, they claimed that he was legitimately extremely angry about her comments.  And then shortly after the election, there were some uprisings in Moscow, and Putin blamed those on Hillary Clinton.  He felt like she was behind those uprisings.  So he accuses her of all of these things.  And there's a lot of bad blood between them.  And he's really suspicious that she's trying to oust him.  So he doesn't trust her at all.  So then Hillary runs for president.  And I think that there's a case to be made that Putin probably did some stuff.
